body.p:
To his Excellency Beriah Magoffin
Governor of Kentucky.

Your petitioner John W Woodward respectfully states, that at the Barren Equity & Criminal Court, he was fined the sum of Two hundred dollars for keeping a Tippling house for three consecutive months. He states that the charge was proven by but one witness, and at the time the charge was made against him, he was a merchant in the town of Edmunton and had a license tofrom the Barren County Court to retail spirituous liquors by the quart, He states that it was untrue that he ever sold any liquors to be drank on the premises or on the premises adjacent thereto, but was in the habit of giving his customers a dram when they bought liquors by the quart, for the purpose of carrying it away. He states that the evidence by the witness was; during some three months prior to the finding of the indictment, that at some several times during the months prior. (the witness not able to state the number of times) that witness had seen your petitioner sell liquors
by the quart, and at the same time, he saw the liquor drank in the house by those who brought liquors by the quart. -- saw money passed, but could not state whether it was paid for the liquor which was carried away, or that which was drank in the house. He states that the witness was a man who was in the habit of drinking liquor, and getting drunk, and often made application to your petitioner ^to get liquor^ by the drink, and in consequence of the refusal to sell him liquor by the drink, witness fell out with with petitioner, went before the grand Jury and indicted him.
Your petitioner is a man is very ordinary circumstances, with a large family to maintain ^and^ and ^in very ill health^ relying upon his business for a support,
Your excellency is well aware of the money crisis. Wherefore your petitioner humbly prays that the Executive clemency be extend to him.

James A Rousseau states that he was present at the trial, and the evidence stated in the petition is about the amount of proof that was made and that he is acquainted with John W Woodward, and that the statements in the petition in relation to his condition and family are true, he is of the opinion that his case is one that deserves the clemency of the Executive and therefore recommends that it be extended to him.

We the undersigned state that we have been acquainted with John W Woodward since the year 1854, and have been about his house since the time he has been doing business in Edmunton, a great deal, and have never known him to sell any liquors to be drank in his house or upon his premises, that we are well acquainted with his circumstanes and know that he has had bad health for the last ten years, and scarcely able to attend to his business. We are fully satisfied that his case is one that deserves the executive
clemency, and therefore candidly recommend it.

R. H. Young
Joseph B Stockton
J. W. Compton
Charles Yates
S, H, Maris
W C Pool
Jas F. Kiel
J R Witty

Barren E & C Ct
Respite 12 Mo
B. M
$200 } Tipling
Jno. W. Woodward
Issd Dec 22d 1860
